revision.text: {{also|yayō}} ==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|yeyo}}, {{l|en|yay}} ===Etymology=== From {{der|en|es|llello}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|en|/ˈjeɪ.oʊ/}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun|-}} # {{lb|en|US|slang}} [[cocaine]] #*{{quote-song|en|artist=Debbie Harry|title=Rush, Rush|passage=Rush-rush to the '''yayo'''; buzz-buzz give me yayo.|publisher=Universal Music Publishing Group|year=1983|album=Scarface|lyricist=Deborah Harry and Giorgio Moroder}} #* '''2004''', Lil' Jon and the East Side Boyz (Jonathan Mortimer Smith), "Grand Finale" (rap song) #*: We '''yayo''' experts, we been whippin' the yola / Since the crackas decided to take the coke from Coca-Cola. #* '''2009''', Christine A. Nandi, ''The ABC's of Raising a Successful Student'' (page 7) #*: They just spend their time sniffing up the '''''yayo'''''. ====Synonyms==== * See also [[Thesaurus:cocaine]]. ---- ==Aragonese== ===Etymology=== {{rfe|an}} ===Noun=== {{an-noun|m|yayos}} # [[grandpa]] ===References=== * {{R:DBLA}} ---- ==Cebuano== ===Etymology=== From {{m|ceb|yaya}}. Compare {{cog|es|yayo}}. ===Noun=== {{head|ceb|noun}} # {{lb|ceb|often|_|humorous}} a male [[nanny]]; a [[manny]] ===Verb=== {{head|ceb|verb}} # {{lb|ceb|often|_|humorous}} to work or act as a [[manny]] {{topics|ceb|People|Occupations|Male}} ---- ==Spanish== ===Etymology=== {{unk|es}} origin, perhaps from whimsical slang by youth. A prevailing theory, given the term's ultimate origin in [[Aragon]] and [[Catalan]]-speaking territories, is derivation from {{bor|es|ca|jajo||grandpa}}. It seems the first form generated was {{m|ca|*jaja||grandma}}, from which the masculine form was derived. This would come from {{der|es|ca|avia||grandmother}} (from {{der|es|VL.|*aviōla}}, feminine diminutive of {{m|la|avus||grandfather}}), and from juvenile [[palatalization]] would generate something like {{m|ca|*ai̯a}}. The common phenomenon of syllabic repetition in children's language (cf. {{m|en|papa}}, {{m|en|baba}}, etc.) would then cause the form {{m|ca|jaja}} above, which would then be spread into Spanish and masculinized. Otherwise, perhaps masculinized from {{der|es|el|γιαγιά||grandmother}}. ===Pronunciation=== {{es-IPA}} ===Noun=== {{es-noun|m}} # {{lb|es|mainly|_|Spain|Catalonia|informal}} [[grandpa]], [[pops]] ====Related terms==== * {{l|es|yaya}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:es:DRAE}} {{C|es|Family}} ---- ==Tagalog== ===Etymology=== From {{bor|tl|es|yayo|gloss=grandpa}}. Compare {{cog|ca|iaio}} and {{cog|ceb|yayo}}. ===Noun=== {{head|tl|noun|feminine|yaya}} # {{lb|tl|often|_|humorous}} a male [[nanny]]; a [[manny]]
